newsitem.title: UK: Tradepoint slides, seeks long-term financing.
newsitem.headline: Tradepoint slides, seeks long-term financing.

text.p: Shares in the Tradepoint Investment Exchange, the main rival to the London Stock Exchange, fell sharply on Tuesday on concern over the company's financial position.

On Monday Tradepoint, which is traded on the Alternative Investment Market in London and the Vancouver Stock Exchange, announced an "interim financing arrangement" in a statement it made following "market rumours" about its financial position.

"The company has, through its broker Williams de Brow, entered into an interim financing arrangement and is pursuing detailed negotiations to secure long-term financing," Tradepoint said in the statement on Monday.
At 1155 GMT its share price in London stood off 25 pence at 70 pence per share, but up from a low of 65 pence.
The concern was that Tradepoint, which is losing money each month, might be put into the hands of an administrator.
A statement about the company's long-term financing plans is expected later this week.

Tradepoint, which offers investors a facility to buy and sell shares electronically in more than 900 British companies, on Tuesday reported 334 trades in May -- the largest number of shares in any month over the past year -- valued at around 56 million stg.
A spokesman for the company said the May average represented 0.3 to 0.4 percent of the total London Stock Exchange turnover.
Tradepoint has said that it needs to hit around two percent to break even.
